article.headline: Utah 59, UNLV 55
article.story:
DENVER (AP) -- Even with the shots clanging off the rim and UNLV
racing off to a big lead, Utah didn't panic.

The Utes had been there too many times.

Shona Thorburn had 13 points and Utah overcame a horrible start
to beat Nevada-Las Vegas 59-55 Friday in the Mountain West
Conference tournament semifinals.

Utah (24-6), the No. 2 seed, needed more than five minutes to
get its first points but rallied in the second half to reach the
conference finals for the first time since winning the tournament
title in 2000. The Utes will face top-seeded New Mexico in the
championship game on Saturday.

"I think we're a very poised and calm team and we really don't
let stuff rattle us," Thorburn said. "We have been done a lot
early in games this year, but we're a very heady team. We don't let
runs get to us."

Third-seeded UNLV (22-7) did a good job of holding two-time
Mountain West player of the year Kim Smith in check -- 10 points on
4-of-10 shooting -- but allowed Utah to shoot 12-for-24 in the
second half.

The Lady Rebels still should have a good shot at reaching the
NCAA tournament, but will have to wait to see if they'll get an
at-large bid on Sunday.

"I definitely think we should be in the dance," said InFini
Robinson, who led UNLV with 17 points. "We beat Richmond, we beat
a lot of good teams this year. And I love to dance, so I'm really
looking forward to Sunday."

Utah struggled most of the first half, but went on a 9-0 run
midway through the second to go up by six. Thorburn gave the Utes
their first lead, 39-38, with a scoop shot at 11:04, and Smith
capped the run with a drive that made it 44-38.

UNLV shot a respectable 44 percent in the first half and was
3-for-4 to open the second half, then went cold. The Lady Rebels
went 10:29 without a field and had five turnovers before Sheena
Moore's long 3-pointer cut Utah's lead to 44-42 with 6:23 left.

Thorburn followed with an improbable hanging three-point play,
and Kelsey Stireman answered Sherry McCracklin's two free throws
with a 3-pointer from the wing that put Utah up 50-44.

UNLV cut the lead to 58-55 on RanDee Henry's layup with 12.7
seconds left, but Thorburn hit 1 of 2 free throws and Moore shot an
airball on the game's final shot.

"A good win for us," Utah coach Elaine Elliott said. "They
started out like they were going to make a game of it. I feel
fortunate the players had a great second half and I'm proud of
their effort."

UNLV certainly got off to a great start.

Robinson opened the game with a 3-pointer from behind the NBA
line and added another from just as far from the other wing to cap
an 11-0 run.

UNLV's defense was just as good, holding the Mountain West's
best shooting team without a field goal more than five minutes.

Utah missed its first four shots and had two turnovers before
Lana Sitterud hit a 3-pointer from the wing 5:48 into the game.
That seemed to spark the Utes, who hit six of their next shots to
close the gap to 19-18.

But Robinson got hot again, hitting hit two more 3-pointers,
including one from just inside half court at the buzzer to put the
Lady Rebels up 30-24 at halftime.
